ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TOTAL DEFENCE
(Public perception and support)


    1. Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence what is his assessment of the public perception and support for Total Defence; and what steps are being taken to ensure that the need for Total Defence is not forgotten.

    The Second Minister for Defence (Policy)(Dr Yeo Ning Hong)(for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the concept of Total Defence was introduced in 1984. Since then the Defence Ministry has conducted annual surveys each year. The surveys showed that most Singaporeans are familiar with the concept of Total Defence. They appreciate the importance of Total Defence and the need for every individual Singaporean to play his part. The latest survey was conducted earlier this year in January, and it showed 78% of Singaporeans agreed with the statement that "With Total Defence, we can discourage others from attacking us." 17% disagreed with that statement, and 5% said "they did not know."

    At the community level, awareness of Total Defence is emphasized through a variety of programmes. They include:

Column: 484



    (1) The various civil defence programmes and emergency exercises for distribution of food, water and fuel.

    (2) Civil resource mobilization (this is when the owners of vehicles like lorries, 3-tonners and trucks bring in their vehicles to allow Mindef to use)

    (3) Open Mobilization. (This is when family members participate by informing their sons, husbands, brothers or cousins that a particular Open Mobilization exercise is on, and get the reservists report quickly to their units.

    In addition to these programmes, the Government also conducts a number of campaigns. They include the "Sing Singapore", "Courtesy", "Community Week" and "Productivity" campaigns, all with the objective of strengthening our Psychological Defence, our Social Defence, our Economic Defence. Overall, the response from the public has been encouraging. The public has demonstrated their support for these exercises and campaigns. We believe that Total Defence is now part and parcel of the individual Singaporean's way of life.

    Taking the long term, we have to ensure that new generations of Singaporeans are familiar, and knowledgeable, about this concept. To do that we have enlisted the assistance and support of the Ministry of Education. We have worked our guidelines on the teaching of Total Defence worked out together with the teachers and principals. These

Column: 485

guidelines are being issued to the principals and teachers in primary and secondary schools. We also encourage teachers to attend national education courses and Total Defence courses, so that they too will have a better understanding of what it is we are trying to achieve, and teach Total Defence to their children, answer their questions and help in the programme for encouraging every Singaporean to play his or her part in Total Defence.

PRIORITY REGISTRATION SCHEME FOR PRIMARY 1 IN 1988
(Enrolment)


    The following question stood in the name of Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon -

    4. To ask the Minister for Education how many parents, who qualify, made use of the priority registration scheme to enrol their children in Primary 1 in 1988.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: Question 4, Sir.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon)(for the Minister for Education): Sir, phase 1 and phase 2 are priority phases under our Primary 1 registration scheme. In 1988, 11,976 children or roughly one-third were registered under phase 1; another 22,107 were registered under phase 2. The total represents 93% of the total number of children registered for admission into Primary 1 classes for 1989.

CONSUMPTION TAX
(Machinery for collection)


    5. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Finance if he will give an estimate of the development and recurrent expenditure for the setting up of the machinery to collect a broad-based consumption tax.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have mentioned in my Budget Statement, a broad-based consumption tax has considerable impact on the economy, especially on individuals and on our export and tourist trade. My Ministry is still considering the form in which such a tax should take in order to minimize its possible

Column: 487

adverse impact, for example, whether it should be a Value Added Tax similar to those introduced in Europe or New Zealand, or a general sales tax at the retail level like the United States or at the wholesale level like Switzerland. Consideration would also be given as to the degree of integration desired between the existing and the new consumption tax, and the number of inspections necessary to police the system to ensure minimal abuse.

    As such, and until these matters have been agreed to, it is rather premature for me to provide an estimate of the expenditure to be incurred in the setting up of the collection machinery. However, the experience of other countries in terms of staffing ratios is interesting, if not indicative. For example, New Zealand employs one staff member for every 304 taxpayers; Italy employs one staff member for every 267 taxpayers; in the Netherlands, one staff member is required for every 190 taxpayers and in the United Kingdom, one staff member is required for every 115 taxpayers. In terms of the initial capital outlay, much depends on whether the existing computer system can be used or if some upgrading is necessary or whether a whole new system need to be purchased. Needless to say, much of the costs to be incurred would depend on the complexity of the consumption tax system adopted.

GRANT FOR PLACING CHILDREN WITH REGISTERED FOSTER MOTHERS


    6. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for Community Development whether he will consider a grant to working mothers who place their children with registered foster mothers.

     The Minister of State for Community Development (Dr Seet Ai Mee) (for the Minister for Community Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    There is no plan to give a grant to working mothers who place their children with registered foster mothers.

    Currently there is a very big pool of foster care-givers including grandparents, relatives, foster mothers, neighbours and others. Such care-givers may or may not be paid. If the Member's suggestion were

Column: 488

implemented, everyone who looks after the child of a working mother will seek to register as "foster mothers' whether she is paid or not. This means that grandparents, relatives and neighbours who now help out willingly and gratis will also register. Maids may also register as foster mothers. In effect, the grant will become a "child allowance".

    The tax incentives and enhanced child relief announced recently are sufficiently attractive. There is no plan for a separate child allowance.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, as far as the working mothers are concerned, is it not the Minister of State's objective with the subsidy that she is giving to subsidize children in day-care centre to help to lighten the burden of working mothers? So why should she discriminate against working mothers who prefer to send their children to registered foster mothers as compared to the child-care centres. Why should there be a discrimination as far as the working mothers are concerned?

     Dr Seet Ai Mee: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is going to be difficult for us to draw the line between the care-giver who can be considered for registration and one who cannot. Control measures to prevent such abuse will be difficult and expensive. So it would be difficult for us to implement this kind of subsidy.

    7. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Labour whether he will review the compensation payable under the Workmen's Compensation Act in the light of the changing industrial structure and economic circumstances.

PERMANENT RESIDENTS
(Purchase of HDB flats with CPF savings)


    8. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Labour if he will consider allowing Singapore permanent residents to use their Central Provident Fund for housing provided their spouse is a Singaporean.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the present HDB regulations allow a Singapore citizen and his or her spouse who is a permanent resident of Singapore to be co-owners of an HDB flat. Such permanent resident co-owners are allowed to use their CPF savings to pay for the HDB flat. The permanent resident must be a co-owner and not just a permitted occupier.

    In the case of private properties, a CPF member can withdraw his CPF savings to purchase a property in Singapore on his own or jointly with members of his immediate family. The CPF member must be the owner or co-owner of the property. The member need not be a Singapore citizen.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tiong Bahru GRC): What about those who have permanent resident status but do not hold blue Singapore ICs. Can they be considered?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: I will have to confirm with HDB on this point, but I think there should be no problem.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Eunos GRC): Sir, when the House adjourned on Friday, the Member for Tampines GRC, Dr Aline Wong, asked the Government to state its stand on pre-primary education. This follows a report by the Auditor-General that the programme be scrapped on the ground that the objectives of the programme no longer exist and it is not cost-effective to conduct pre-primary classes in schools.

    To briefly recap, the programme was started in 1979 to try to arrest the declining enrolment in Chinese medium schools and to help children from dialect-speaking homes learn English and Chinese languages. This programme is presently offered not to all schools but only to 39 out of the 210 primary schools. Sir, the need to arrest the declining enrolment in Chinese-medium schools no longer existed following the Ministry's decision in 1987 to make English the main medium of instruction in our schools.

    I believe a study conducted by the Ministry in 1984 shows that after three years of primary education there was little significant difference between the language abilities of children who attended pre-primary classes and those who attended kindergarten classes run by private and community organizations.

    Sir, I am aware that this pre-primary programme is popular among parents. I agree that education is about investment in human resources and we must not stinge on that. But I believe it is also our responsibility, as Members in this Chamber, to ensure that taxpayers' monies are properly spent. The cost of running the pre-primary programme works out to about $120 per child per month. This cost is much higher than the average cost of about $12 to $90 per child per month spent by non-MOE kindergartens which we refer to private kindergartens as well as kindergartens run by community organizations.

    I understand that it will cost the State something like $80-$100 million annually to run the pre-primary programme if this programme is extended to all schools in Singapore, ie, to all the 210 primary schools. This is a big sum. The opportunity

Column: 491

cost to the State if we were to continue with this programme is just too high. The kindergarten classes conducted by the private sector and community organizations could take over this role.

    Sir, I am aware that parents are concerned about the standard of education offered by some of these kindergartens. I wish to allay their fear as I believe that most of these kindergartens, particularly those run by the PAP Community Foundation and the People's Association, have invested large sums of money in recent years upgrading and re-equipping. Teachers are now better trained. The curriculum has been restructured to place greater emphasis on developing the child's language ability (and that was the objective of the pre-primary programme) as well as to develop the child socially, emotionally and academically.

    Sir, I also understand that parents are concerned about the higher fees charged by kindergartens. This is inevitable. In the longer run, the operating costs will have to increase with efforts to continue to improve and uphold the standard of kindergarten education in Singapore. But we must try to maintain our kindergarten fees within affordable means of the average Singaporeans. To achieve this, may I suggest that the Minister for Education consider using part of the money saved from scrapping the pre-primary programme to subsidize kindergarten education in the same way as the Government subsidizes child care centres.

     Mr Peh Chin Hua (Jalan Besar GRC)( In Mandarin): Sir, when we talk about traditional values and religious knowledge education, we cannot leave out Confucianism. I would like to say that I regret very much Mr Chiam See Tong's talk and views on Confucianism last Friday. He said that it is a retrogressive action to teach Confucianism and Asian values in schools as it would hinder the development of a democratic society. Mr Chiam is mixing up Confucianism with feudalism. I doubt whether he understands Confucian values in the Eastern traditional culture. So he gave adverse comments on the Government's policy in teaching Confucianism in schools and compared Confucianism with

Column: 492

the feudal system of rule in ancient imperial China. He said Confucianism is a stumbling block for democracy. Sir, if by teaching Confucianism in schools is to consolidate our political power, then scrapping it or teaching anti-Confucianism thoughts would be a measure for democracy! Just recall some two decades ago in mainland China during the period of Cultural Revolution when Confucianism was criticized, attacked and maligned thoroughly, the Government then was not democratic at all. There was only the personality cult of Mao in place of democracy. But now Mr Chiam See Tong is also against the teaching of Confucianism. Does he mean to emulate Mao Tse Tung's Great Cultural Revolution? Or, is he trying to mould a personal image of heroism to enhance his prestige? I hope Mr Chiam See Tong would not brag on his views of something which he has merely a tunnel view.

    Next, talking about religious knowledge education, I agree to the views expressed by Dr Aline Wong. I would ask the Minister about the possibility of teaching Comparative Religious Studies in the class instead. Since 1984, there has been teaching of religious knowledge of one religion for one class system without touching on any general knowledge about other religions. Some students dare not even learn about any rudimentary history and tenets of other religions for fear of offending the religious regulations of their own faiths. So some students who have no inkling of any Bible Knowledge think that belief in Christian or Catholic faith is westernization and a denial of one's own culture and root. Some students without any knowledge of Buddhism or Taoism regard belief in these religions as a sort of cultism, feudalism, devil-related or superstition. To such people, the learning of Confucianism is also revival of feudalism and against the trend of modernization. This kind of thinking is caused by the students' own religious excluvism and extremism. If this kind of situation were to continue for long, it will have unfavourable effect on the inter-religious harmony in our country and also negative effect on our promotion of religious tolerance and mutual understanding.

Column: 493



    At the moment, some teachers make use of class-rooms as churches or temples, while teaching in classes they would also be preaching their own religions. This has incurred the dissatisfaction and concern of certain parents. I hope the Minister would abolish the teaching of religious knowledge in schools or accept what Mr Wong Kan Seng has suggested, ie, change to teaching the subject on major religions instead, so that students may know something about those religious history and what enlightenment and influence they have over human history and, at the same time, learn from the historical angle of religious conflicts and wars to get enlightenment of their mind. In this way, it will help the students to formulate common value concept and a sense of identity.

     The Minister for Education (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Sir, the subject of core values and how to inculcate core values in our children was raised by several Members during the debate last Friday and this subject has also been very widely discussed in the press in the last few months. What I would like to do, Sir, this afternoon is two things. First of all, to give a perspective on the subject and, second, to outline a practical measure which the Ministry will be taking with regard to the dissemination of core values in our schools.

    I believe, Sir, we can understand why, after so many years, the retention of core values has now become an issue by looking at the enrolment figures in our schools over the last 30 years. These figures are given in an Annex which I will ask the Clerk of Parliament to distribute. [Copies of Annexes (Cols. 567 - 570) distributed to hon. Members]. Let me summarize the main points.
Annexes - ENROLMENT OF PUPILS IN PRIMARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOLS BY LANGUAGE MEDIUM, CHOICE OF CL1/CL2 AT PSLE IN 4 PRIMARY SCHOOLS (Cols. 567 - 570)


    First, prior to 1960, more children were educated in Chinese, Malay or Tamil medium schools than in English schools. In fact, children who were educated in English medium schools were in the minority. But after Independence and with the growing economic success of Singapore the importance of learning English as a subject for economic purposes and as a common working language among the

Column: 494

races in Singapore became evident. A good knowledge of English became the passport to a good job and to bright prospects. This was realized by parents and they responded to this trend by enrolling their children in English medium schools in preference to Chinese, Malay and Tamil medium schools. The process went on inexorably so that by the mid-1980s, Chinese, Malay and Tamil medium schools had been phased out and all schools were converted to a national system of education whereby all pupils learn English as their first language and their mother tongue as their second language - CL2, ML2 and TL2. The only exception was in the nine secondary SAP (Special Assistance Plan) schools and the four primary schools which continued to teach CL1 in addition to EL1.

    I think a question which would be pertinent to ask, Sir, is whether it was right for us to encourage Singaporeans to use English as a common working language and to accommodate the wishes of parents for an English medium education for their children. I am sure there will be many views but in my own view, Sir, I believe that there really was no choice. Without the widespread use of English, we would not today have a thriving, prosperous Singapore.

    Let me give you my reasons. There are three of them. First, I believe for racial harmony in a multi-racial society like Singapore, you need one common working language which all races understand and can use for communication with one another. Otherwise, misunderstanding and suspicion can easily arise and multi-racial peace and harmony will come under strain. Singapore is perhaps unique among the countries which have gained their independence in adopting a pragmatic policy towards language and emphasizing the importance of English even at the risk of somewhat lowering the importance of the mother tongue. Perhaps this is one of the reasons, Sir, why we have succeeded when so many other developing countries have failed.

    The second reason, Sir, is that a knowledge of English made it possible for us to

Column: 495

have rapid economic development by rapidly absorbing technology from the West without a need for massive translation facilities which would have been impossible for a small country like Singapore. Indeed, Sir, many companies say that one of the attractions of Singapore as a centre for investments is their ability to start up factories here more quickly than in other countries because of the ability of our people to understand instructions in English, thereby enabling the company to transfer manufacturing processes rapidly to Singapore.

    The third, and I think in some ways the most important reason, is that without the widespread use of English I do not think that it would have been possible for us to build up the Singapore Armed Forces quickly and so effectively as we have done. We need economic success to give us the means to buy arms and equipment. Then of course the technical manuals and instructions are in English and you cannot build up an armed force quickly if all the manuals and instructions have to be translated into three languages which would have been necessary in a multi-racial society like Singapore if we do not have English as our common working language. Without a strong economy, without a strong SAF, there simply would be no Singapore today as we know it today.

    Sir, I made these points in order to put the issue in perspective. But like everything else in life, there is a price for success and the price for Singapore is that for educating our people and our children in English as a key to the technological knowledge of the West, we also inadvertently expose them to cultural influences, attitudes and habits of the West. Our people by being educated in English do not need to read books in translation as is the case in Japan, Taiwan and Indonesia. They are able to read published materials directly from the West and see television programmes directly. And this openness is accentuated by the development of television as the most pervasive medium of communication in the world today. Television, Sir, has made closer the realization of one world where events that take place in one country can be instantaneously transmitted with great emotional impact to

Column: 496

citizens in many other countries around the world. Whether it is soap operas, situation comedies or momentous events like the funeral of the Emperor in Japan or the destruction of the space shuttle "Challenger" in America - all these can be immediately perceived by our children in Singapore. And this daily dose of television material from the West must, over time, have a significant impact on our children's attitudes and outlook towards life. This is why we are today talking about why it is necessary to retain our core values in a situation where we have emphasized and encouraged the use of English as a common working languageand exposed our people and our children to the media, particularly television from the West.

    How do we go about inculcating core values in our children? I think the answer is not with the schools. The answer is with the home. Inculcation of core values must begin with the home. Children absorb core values even before they go to school. They learn them from their parents, grandparents, relatives. When children are young, they are natural imitators. They see what adults do, how adults behave in the home and outside the home, and they follow. If there is an environment of politeness and respect in the home, these values are absorbed by children, as if by osmosis. You do not have to teach them consciously. But the values will remain with the children for a long, long time. So it must begin in the home, but it can be consolidated in the schools.

    Within the school structure, Sir, inculcation of core values is best done during the primary school years. This is because during the primary school years, from ages 6 to 12, these are the years where children's impressions and characters are still being formed and attitudes are being shaped. By the time the child gets to secondary school, it is unlikely that there will be the same impact as in primary school when the lessons can be vividly impressed in his or her mind.

    Now, Sir, what principles should we follow in the teaching of core values in schools? From the debate last Friday, it is generally agreed that the inculcation of

Column: 497

core values cannot be effective if it is confined to a subject that is taught only at specific times and by specific teachers. As noted by the Member for Moulmein and the Non-Constituency Member of Parliament, Dr Lee Siew-Choh, it is the ethos of the school. It is the example of the teachers that play the decisive role in the transmission of core values to pupils in school. A school that is well run and orderly, where there is a proper relationship between the teacher and the pupils, where there is an air of politeness, respect and consideration - I think that that school itself is a better vehicle for the transmission of core values than any formal lessons that we can devise.

    Last Friday Dr Lee Siew-Choh in his speech made a point that many of the Chinese stream schools in the old days, particularly the primary schools, used to teach good traditional values particularly good manners. I think he has made a valid point.

    In fact, in 1979, noting the rapidly declining enrolment in the Chinese medium primary schools, the Government introduced a pre-primary programme in order to arrest the declining enrolment in the Chinese medium schools and to provide the foundation for the learning of languages. become redundant. This has led some Chinese teachers to feel that their roles have diminished in importance.
